CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 11, 1950, p. 7, reads: "From Old Deal to Fair Deal - Duke Finch changed his registration last week from Republican to Democrat, and following his lead, as she has done for the past sixty-five years, Mrs. Finch changed hers too. Mr. Finch Explained that he had been voting for the Democrats since they days of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, but wanted to vote for them in primary. - Harris Photo."Cropped image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 18, 1959, pg. 9, with accompanying article reading: "Matriarch of 94 Offsprings Dies - Mrs. Priscilla Finch, matriarch of a family of 94 died April 12, at her home, 2261 Bedford Ave., at the age of 93.  The deceased, who was affectionately called 'Mother Finch,' was the widow of the late Duke Finch, and ex-slave who preceded her in death seven years ago at the age of 107.  They were among Pittsburgh's oldest residents and had become legendary figures because of their large family and extremely good health in advanced years.  Friends are being received at Charles Funeral Home.  Services will be held at the Church of God and Saints of Christ, April 23 at 1 P. M. Elder Joseph Morris will officiate.  The 94 survivors include one daughter, Mrs. Gertrude Jefferson; 25 grandchildren, 57 great-grandchildren, and 11 great-great-grandchildren.  Joseph Finch, proprietor of Herron-Centre Drug Store is a grandson of the deceased."
TitMainTitle: Priscilla Finch and Duke Finch standing behind cake with candles, possibly in their home at 2261 Bedford Avenue, Hill District
